Key Arguments: The government should not police information online unless it involves blatantly criminal activity.
Determining misinformation or disinformation is subjective and should not be decided by government entities.
The scientific model encourages questioning and debate, which is essential for free speech.
Government entities have shown inadequacy in interpreting information, as demonstrated by the author's personal experience with COVID-19 vaccine mandates.
The legislation empowers the government inappropriately and threatens free speech.
Main Themes: Free speech and the right to question authority
Government overreach and lack of trust in government judgment
Notable Quotes: I inherently do NOT believe it is the governmentâ€™s role to police information posted online unless it contravenes Common law and Civil law.
The government is not qualified to determine what is misinformation or disinformation.
This Communication Legislation Amendment for mis/disinformation online is designed to empower government and it is government that should not be allowed to determine what is 'truth' online.
